title: Finding the slope of linear equations
summary:
Linear equations are written in the standard form \(y = mx + b\) Where \(b\) is the \(y\)-intercept of the equation and \(m\) is the slope, which is how much y changes with a change in x.

In this form, solving for the slope is a simple matter, it's simply \(m\). For example, if  \(y=7x+3\), then the slope (\(m\)) is simply 7. However we may receive the equation in a different form however, such as \(8x+4y=12\), in which case it's usually best to transform the equation back in to standard form and find \(m\) directly.
\[ 8x + 4y =12 \rightarrow 4y = 12-8x \rightarrow y = 3-2x\]
so /(m = 2/)

Additionally, instead of an equation, we may simply recieve two points, \((x_1, y_1),(x_2,y_2)\) and be asked to find the slope between them. In this case, we find the "rise over run" which is the difference in the \(y-values\) divided by the difference in the \(x-values\) \[ m = \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \]. i.e. for the two points \((0, 6),(2,10)\) then \((x_1 = 0, y_1= 6),(x_2 = 2,y_2 = 10)\), so \[m = \frac{10-6}{2-0} =\frac{4}{2} = 2\]

title: Finding the slope of a polynomial
summary: Polynomials are written in the form \[y = a_0 x^n + a_1 x^{n-1} +.... +a_{n-1} x + a_n\] The power rule states the derivative of a monomial is \[\frac{d}{dx}x^n = nx^{n-1} \] The superposition rules tells us that the derivative of the sum of terms is equal to the sum of the derivates, i.e. \[\frac{d}{dx} (f(x)+g(x)] = f'(x) + g'(x) \] putting together these facts together, we can find the derivative of any polynomial

title: Derivatives using the chain rule
summary: Equations of the form \[y = a_0 x^n + a_1 x^{n-1} +.... +a_{n-1} x + a_n\]

title: Solving exponential equations
summary: Exponential equations of the form \[y = a_0 x^n + a_1 x^{n-1} +.... +a_{n-1} x + a_n\]

title: Finding Quadratic roots
summary:
A quardratic has the form \[(1) y = ax^2 + b x + c\], where /(a>0/). A quardratic function can 0,1, or 2 y-intercepts, also known as roots.  
 We can find the roots by setting the function equal to 0 and solving for x. When \(b =0\) and \(c\ =0) the equation becomes \(ax^2 =0\) which has only the trivial solution, \(x=0\)
 
 In the case /(c=0/) the equation becomes \[y = ax^2 + b x = 0 \rightarrow (ax+b)(x) = 0 \rightarrow x=0, x = -b/a \]

When \(b=0\) the equation becomes \[y = ax^2 + c = 0 \rightarrow (x^2) = -c/a \rightarrow x=\pm \sqrt{-c/a} \] Which will yield two real solutions if \(\frac{-c}{a} > 0\), otherwise, both solutions would be imaginary.

Finally, if all terms are non-zero the solution becomes less trivial. The first method used is usually factoring. If we have a quadratic written in the form \((x-a)(x-b)\) we can see that the roots are simply \((x=a)(x=b)\). If we distribute this equation, we get \(x^2-(b+a)x+ba)\). Using this as a template, we can go backwards. for example \[x^2+2x-8\] \rightarrow a*b = 8, b+a = -2\)

Solving the system of linear equations, we can see that \(b=-4\) and \(a=2\) , which are the roots of the equation

If factoring proves difficult, the quadratic equation is a full proof, if not somewhat cumbersome, method to solve for quadratic roots
\[\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} \]
Where we simply plug in the coeffecients from eq 1 and we'll recieve the roots of the function
